resource.chars:
Plate X
Various appearances presented by the surfaces
of disks, simple and complex: all magn<sup>d</sup> - 35 diam.

1. Simple disk (from Australia) <s>the</s> slightly concave, the mar-
ginal cells laid open by abrasion, the surface irregularly
thickened by <s>d</s> calcareous deposits.
2. Simple plate-shaped disk, with one edge turned-up,
showing the true marginal pores.
3. Simple disk, slightly concave, the marginal cells laid
open by abrasion, the surface marked rather by
'engine-turned' or eccentric <s>circles</s>, than by concentric circles.
4. Portion of the surface of a simple disk, showing unusu-
ally large and protuberant ovoidal cells.
5. Simple plate-shaped disk (from Australia), with well
marked concentric rows of large ovoidal cells, and irregu-
lar superficial deposits.
6. Portion of the surface of a complex disk, having
small, <s>fl</s> round, and flattened superficial cells.
7. Portion of the surface of another complex disk, showing
